svg.text: Extended Archetypes, Recovery Strategies, and Multi-Scale Product Development

g.text: I. The Multi-Scale Framework: Shots → Holes → Courses
The atomic unit of development. Each shot moves
through embedding space, landing in a specific
A sequence of shots from initial concept to feature-
complete implementation. Each hole has a par
Multiple features compose a complete product.
Each hole (feature) contributes to overall product
II. Extended Shot Archetypes: The Complete Golfer's Toolkit
When: On the green, near goal convergence
Purpose: Fine-tuning final details with minimal changes
When: Starting from tee, broad exploration needed
Purpose: Cover maximum semantic distance quickly
When: Need to work around obstacles/constraints
Purpose: Intentional trajectory bending for specific outcome
• "Like X, but with Y approach instead"
When: Development went off-track, outside target zone
Purpose: Get back to playable area (fairway/rough)
• Feature scope creep beyond original intent
When: Recovery impossible, need to backtrack
Purpose: Return to known-good position (penalty stroke)
Confidence: Reset to previous position's level
• "Go back to initial concept, new direction"
When: Near goal, need vertical specificity
Purpose: Land softly in precise zone with high control
• "Add these three fields to the form"
When: Early mistake, no penalty desired
Purpose: Informal retry without counting stroke
• First prompt was too vague, rephrase
When: Just off green, close but not quite there
Purpose: Get onto green for final putt
When: Risk too high to go for green directly, play safe
Purpose: Position for optimal next shot, avoid hazards
• Complex feature: "First, build basic version without advanced features"
• Unclear requirements: "Create simple prototype to validate approach"
• Tech uncertainty: "Implement with standard library, optimize later if needed"
• Time constrained: "Get MVP working, polish in subsequent iteration"
When: Constrained environment, need to stay under obstacles
Purpose: Low trajectory to avoid overhead constraints
• Legacy system constraints: "Work within existing architecture, no major refactor"
• Limited permissions: "Use available APIs, no system-level changes"
• Performance budget: "Optimize within current memory/CPU limits"
• Backward compatibility: "Maintain support for older versions"
III. Hazards & Out-of-Bounds: When Development Goes Astray
OUT OF BOUNDS (OB): Beyond the Scope
Development has drifted so far from original goal that recovery would
cost more than restarting. No clear path back to target zone.
• Original requirements are unrecognizable in current implementation
• Feature has 5x the complexity it should have
• You've built something impressive but completely wrong
• Each new iteration makes things worse, not better
• No one (including you) understands what you're building anymore
Revert to last known-good state (e.g., 5-10 iterations ago)
Accept penalty: wasted effort, but you're back in playable position
Learn: Document what went wrong to avoid repeating
Getting stuck in complex dependency chains, version conflicts,
breaking changes. Hard to navigate, easy to get mired.
Recovery: Simplify dependencies, use conservative versions
Accumulated quick fixes, workarounds, and shortcuts that slow
progress. Requires extra strokes to escape.
Recovery: Refactor systematically, don't make it worse
Ambiguous goals, vague specifications. Progress is slow and
Recovery: Clarify requirements before proceeding further
KEY PRINCIPLE: Recognize hazards early, take recovery shot ASAP
IV. The Development Scorecard: Tracking Product Progress
An 18-hole course represents a complete product. Track your development journey:
PRODUCT DEVELOPMENT SCORECARD: E-Commerce Platform MVP
V. Strategic Insights: Putting It All Together
Different features have different difficulty. Set realistic expectations
for iteration count based on archetype.
Don't try hero shots beyond your skill level. Consistent progress
beats risky attempts that land out of bounds.
Model capabilities, token limits, context length—these are the
weather conditions of your course. Adjust strategy accordingly.
When to Use Each Shot Type
In Trouble: Recovery, Drop—get back on track
High Risk Ahead: Layup, Punch—play conservative

svg.text: "Golf is a game of misses. Development is a journey of iterations."
The goal isn't perfection on the first shot—it's strategic, persistent progress toward the green.
Development-as-Golf: Expanded Edition © 2025 — Complete Archetype Framework
